turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

I would say that our position is that since the usual employment is a specific factor that's listed in section 908(h), that really is the key determination, whether or not his injury affects or impairs his ability to perform his usual employment, his usual pre-injury employment, and here there's no argument that it did.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but that will... I guess that takes me back to Justice Ginsburg's question.
Except for the employee who in fact fully recovers, your theory will always support a nominal award.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: I don't believe so, Your Honor, because I believe that in this case the usual employment is a broad category term, and he was a longshoreman before this accident.
He's still a longshoreman.

He happens to be doing lighter duty crane job work, but the great majority of longshore work does require a lot of physical labor, and there's no question that his disability impairs his ability to do the great majority of longshore jobs that do require physical labor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So if he had gotten another job as an accountant, let's say, he got retrained as an accountant, that wouldn't at all affect his entitlement to awards.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: I guess... I think it would depend on the evidence, but I would concede--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Unless he was an accountant for... I guess the longshore companies have accountants, don't they?
[Laughter]
What don't longshore companies have.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: --There's a wide variety of jobs.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: There must be something they don't have.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: But what I would say in that regard is that I can envision circumstances where a claimant has so completely changed industries, become an accountant or a doctor or a lawyer, that in no way would ever require physical labor, and he has also come forward, or someone has come forward with evidence indicating that there is very little chance that he will lose that type of job, that complete termination could be justified.
I just don't think it is appropriate in this case.
Your Honors, the mechanism of nominal awards fulfills the forward-looking perspective of 908(h) and it lifts the onerous burden from the ALJ.

It lifts the burden inherent in any attempt to pick a disability figure out of thin air, as the circuit courts have stated, rather than simply assigning a nominal value and allowing it to be changed at a later date.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Just out of curiosity, do... is it your perception that employers generally like it this way, or generally would rather have the ALJ guess as to what the future will be?

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: That's an interesting question--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: --and I can't give you an answer to that.
All I know is they're--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This doesn't split out necessarily on the basis of plaintiffs' versus defendants' preference.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: --I think employers generally don't like to have nominal awards because they have to keep their cases open, and they have to keep looking at cases, rather than closing them.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Pierry.

turn.speaker: thomas_j_pierry
turn.label: Mr. Thomas J. Pierry, III
turn.text: Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.
